1.mnemonic: This radical is shaped like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>. Kind of like the barb you'd see on a barbed fishing hook. Imagine that thing getting stuck in your arm or something. Not exactly pleasant. Say out loud, "Oh dang, I got a barb stuck in me!" Alright, relax, it's only a little barb.

This radical looks just like a stick figure‚Äîmore specifically, a really <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> guy with his arms stretched out nice and big. When you see this radical, just think big, because this guy is really BIG!

You know those big steel girders that are used for the frame of big buildings? This is like the end of one of those, and has a very distinct shape, just like this radical. These girders are used in construction, which is why this radical means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark>. Funny thing is, you use these girders to put together buildings just like you're going to use this radical to put together kanji!
This radical looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>. I mean, just look at it. Two bars going through each other = a cross!

This little radical is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>, maybe of water or some other liquid. Notice how it's only one drop? Sometimes radicals and kanji will have more than one drop in them, but don't let that throw you off.

Watch out! This isn't the person radical, it's something else. What's the difference? The right side is longer than the left. This radical also has that extra part sticking out at the top. See it? It kind of looks like a person lowering their head to go inside a tent or something. That's why this radical is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">enter</mark>.

These look like <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>. What's a pair of disembodied fins doing here?! Some fish must have left them here by accident. Bet they're really missing these fins right about now.

This radical consists of a single, horizontal stroke. What's the biggest, single, horizontal stroke? That's the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. Look at the ground, look at this radical, now look at the ground again. Kind of the same, right?

This looks a lot like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> pointing to the right. You have a handle on the left, and the barrel pointing to the right. Imagine it hanging in a case on the wall in a museum.

This looks like something you'd put on a kettle or a pot, right? It even has a little handle to make sure you don't burn yourself. This is some kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark>.
This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>. See the big peak in the middle and the smaller ones on either side? This totally looks like a mountain.
A big, gaping, square hole represents someone opening their giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to tell you something stupid.

If you look at this radical in just the right way, you'll notice that it kind of looks like the letters "n" and "i" (the "i" comes from the little flippy-up stroke on the right side). What do the letters "n" and "i" start spelling? Why, the word <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark>.

This is a person. They're standing with their arms down at their sides and their legs spread out, which kind of makes them look like a torso with a pair of legs. Think of ‰∫∫ as highlighting the bipedal nature of people. Walking on two legs? Probably a person.
Imagine a guy flexing his arm downward to show off his steroid-pumped arm. It's huge. It's so full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>. RARRRWWWRRR!!

This looks like an enclosure of sorts ‚Äî that's why it's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>. Imagine a tiny prisoner curled up inside, staring off into space, completely convinced they're trapped forever. Ironically this prison is actually wide open. They're just so consumed with self-pity that they haven't realized they've been free to leave all along.

This radical already looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>. See how the lines represent the flow of the river? There's even a slight bend in this river. So when you see this radical, you should think "river."

What does this radical look like? Hmm, nothing much. What about if you turn it upside down? Now does it look like a 7 with a line through it? Close enough to help you to remember that this radical is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark>, right? Just remember, when you see this radical, flip it over and see what number it looks like. If you can do that, you can remember the meaning!

Close your eyes and imagine you're a kid again. Now open them and... look! It's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>! Imagine little you sliding down this slide over and over, having a great time. Imagination + emotion makes for good memorization!
This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark>, sticking straight up. It even looks like a stick.

Since there are no circles in Japanese characters, sometimes rectangles or squares have to make do. In this case, this big rectangle is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. The middle line is a cloud, moving across the sun. Picture it, but don't actually look at the sun and burn your eyes!

This radical kind of looks like a toe. See the one weird toe coming off the side of it? This also looks like the katakana character „Éà (to), which sounds like the word "toe." So whenever you see „Éà, just think toe.

Do you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in here? It has branches, and then it has the foliage coming down diagonally from it, spreading out like a tree would. That's why this radical is a tree.

One line plus another line equals <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> lines. This radical represents the number two. Pretty simple, right? Can you guess what three looks like? I bet you can...
This radical looks like a woman curtsying. Another way to think of it could be as two stacked Xs, since women generally have XX chromosomes.

2.mnemonic: What's something useful you can get out of a tree? A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">book</mark>! Just cut that book right out of the tree trunk. If you think about it, every tree contains unlimited book potential. It's just a shame they have to be cut down to make the books‚Ä¶

This radical looks like a fancy composite <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> people would use to shoot at targets and definitely not any normal living animals. See how the middle part is being pulled back? Imagine holding this bow and firing it at a target shaped like a giant alligator-crab monster.

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark>. Aww, see how they're wearing a cap and have their little arms stretched out? You can almost hear them saying "pick me up!" A very child-like child.

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> radical. It kind of looks like the long face of a cow, right? Specifically a boy cow, since you can think of that top horizontal line as its horns. Seeing it yet? It's got a little tuft of hair on its head, and some kind of accessory on the horn to your left, so this is a very stylish cow.

At first this looks like a cross in the ground, but it's actually something growing in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. It's a little sprout, already rocking three leaves. And it's all thanks to that dirt! When you see this radical, think about how amazing it is that things just, like, grow in the dirt.

Remember the big guy who helped you with that big radical? Now you've got his big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">DOG</mark>! You know it's a dog because he's lying down, legs all spread out, with his favorite bone right beside his head.

This is the top half of a moon peeking out as it begins to rise. When does that happen? In the evening! Don't confuse this with the moon radical Êúà. Â§ï is for the evening, when the moon's still low enough to be partly covered (by a mountain, for example).

See the iris in the middle of the eyeball? Remember that there are no round things in kanji, so square things take their place. That makes this a pretty realistic, square <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>. You just have to squint with your real eyes a bit.
This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>. It's got three little flames on top and even a couple logs underneath.

If you use your imagination, this radical actually looks like the number "5." You just have to remove the vertical line in the bottom left, plus a few extra ends that stick out here and there. Once you do that, you have an easy way to remember that this radical means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark>.
See the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> in this radical? There's a pole with a flag on the end of it, blowing in the wind. Basically, this radical looks just like a flag.
These three streaks look like the flowing locks of someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>. Pretty easy to see and remember that this is the hair radical, right?

This is the hand radical. If you look at the palm of your right hand, the lines in it probably kinda look like the lines in Êâã. Sure it's not a perfect match, and everyone's got different hands, but basically this radical looks like the lines in your hand.

This is the outline of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark>. A really square head, admittedly, but try to imagine it facing to the right. The left side is the back of the head, and the barb-like part on the right shows the curve of the chin. See the head?

Remember the guy from the big radical? This is him again, but this time he's so big his head is touching <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>. He's looking up and has his arms stretched open toward heaven, and his big hair is poking into those heavenly clouds.

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> radical. Picture this king sitting on his solid, squarish throne. The top stroke is the high back of the throne. The cross in the middle is his body, with his arms spread out on the arm rests. The bottom stroke is the ground. See him sitting there now, looking all dignified. Talk about a kingly king.

There's a leaf on top and a stem going down out of it, making this the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> radical. It's a pretty wide and flat leaf, so if it helps you can imagine it as a lily pad leaf.

This radical already looks like a pair of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>. There's even feet on these legs. That's how you know these are legs and not fins (or something else).

This is a stick going through the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of a mouth. What kind of mouth? Mouth of a cylinder, mouth of a box, a human mouth ‚Äî whatever kind you want to imagine, as long as the stick is going through the middle of it, since this is the radical for "middle."

This is the moon radical. See how it looks like a crescent moon with a couple of little clouds floating by? Try not to mix this up with the evening radical Â§ï ‚Äî you can see the whole crescent moon this time, so obviously this should be the radical for moon!

This radical looks like a narwhal. See the tail at the bottom, and the majestic narwhal horn poking out at the top? It also looks like the katakana character „Éä (na), so you can remember it that way too. Na-na-na-narwhal! Just be careful not to confuse this with the treasure radical („É°). The sideways line for that one is at more of a downward angle, like an "X." But the sideways line for narwhal is horizontal („Éä).

This is a little triangle that's almost completely closed off. When you want to be alone, you hide in a place where you can be in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark>. That's why this is the private radical. You're closing yourself off to the rest of the world, with just a little peephole.

In Japan rice paddies are made up of square fields with irrigation lines going between them. See the four rice paddies with water flowing between and around them? That's why this radical is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>.

You see two fins around a barb, but when you look closer, you realize those fins are actually two tiny fish. Think how small these fins (and fish) would have to be to look so much smaller than an already small barb. Talk about small fry‚Ä¶ Yeah, that's why this is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark>.

This looks like someone in a standing position with legs planted firmly on the ground, spreading their arms out in a T-pose to maintain balance. So that makes this the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>.

There's a stick and a giant toe stuck in the ground. Imagine walking along and seeing these things in your path. What would you do? Most likely come to a complete <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>. You know, because of the toe. I guess a normal stop sign wasn't good enough, so they also put up this big toe to really get people to stop.

Imagine viewing this one from above ‚Äî looks like a couple of streets, right? Maybe a three-way intersection at the top there? Well, that's why this is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark>.

This is the sword radical. The „Éé part is the curvy sword, while the rest is a samurai bowing deeply, like 90 degrees, as he holds that sword ‚Äî probably before a sword fight. By the way, don't confuse this with the power radical (Âäõ). See the difference? In the sword radical (ÂàÄ), the „Éé doesn't pierce through the bowing samurai. (Lucky for him.)

You have a slide supported by a big cross, which makes it so strong it can hold a lot of people at once. How many? A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">THOUSAND</mark>! Imagine a thousand people going down this slide. You can hear a voice trying to count them as they go: "ONE! TWO! THREE HUNDRED! FIVE HUNDRED!" and so on. Finally the last person slides down and the voice calls out: "A THOUSAND!" You think it's over, but just as that group finishes, in come another thousand‚Ä¶

This radical is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> because "X marks the spot," as they say. Doesn't it look like the X on a pirate treasure map? You want to go find that treasure now, right?!

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>. It's the water radical because it kind of looks like water coming out of a faucet and splashing everywhere. See how it flows off in different directions too? Very water-like! As water-like as a radical can be, anyway‚Ä¶

Add a drop of the sun to something and it will turn it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark>. The sun is really strong, so even a single drop will burn anything white. Why do you think so many beaches are white? Even the drops of sunblock you use to stop the sun's rays is white. So when you think of sun drops, think white.

This looks like a stool with a lid on it, but it's actually a desk for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark>. Do you see it? You can even see the pen sticking up in the middle. Think of all the beautiful writing that's been produced here. Letters, novels, essays ‚Äî any kind of writing you can think of.

3.mnemonic: This is a gun on top of a big person. The gun is big too, obviously. Why is this big guy's gun so big? Because it shoots <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark>s! Bullets are pretty small, so the guns that shoot them can be any size. But you need a big gun if you want to shoot a big arrow, right? That's why this is the radical for arrow.
The sun AND the moon are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bright</mark> outside.

This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>. See the cloth draping down and the little point at the middle holding it up? You could sit under here and enjoy a bright summer day without getting any sun!
This radical looks like a dude running off to the right. He's heading in a very distinct <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark>. Which direction was it again?

This one looks like a flag, but don't be fooled ‚Äî it's got a line over the top of it, kind of like a door frame. That makes this a little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark>. Specifically a swinging door, with the vertical line on the left being its door hinge. Kind of a weird door, it's true, but you can see it, right?

This looks like a clothesline pole you would <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> clothes on. It's got two very straight horizontal poles, for maximum drying efficiency. If you were gonna dry your clothes, you'd dry them on this thing.

This looks like the guy from the big radical, but he's got something extra on his belly. That's his exposed belly button, because he's a sumo wrestler now: big and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fat</mark>. In sumo, more fat means more power, so imagine he's been training to get as strong and fat as possible.

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">father</mark> radical, since you can see a very fatherly face in it ‚Äî two droopy eyes at the top, a big nose in the middle, and a mustache flaring out at the bottom. Sort of a generic older gentleman father-type face, isn't it?

This looks like a long index finger bent at the bottom, with several other stubby fingers growing out of it on either side. That makes it the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> radical. A bit creepy, but imagine how easily you could grip something or scratch your back with fingery fingers like these. Pretty nice, right?

Do you remember the hair radical? This is like that, except now the hair is attached to a tail. Animals don't usually have hair though. Instead, they have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fur</mark>.
Do you know those rice paddy hats? The ones shaped just like this radical? That's why this radical is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>.

Take a good look at this one. It kind of looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. Not the heart emoji kind, but a real-deal beating heart. Basically, there's a lump in the middle (the heart), and three lines that make up the arteries. Okay, so it's not the most anatomically correct heart, but just look at those floppy arteries going in and out, doing their thing and keeping you alive. What's not to love?

Remember the radical for drop (of liquid)? Looks like it's shattered into two pieces here, which means it must be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> now. You know, since a drop could only break in two after turning into ice.

Remember the sprout from the dirt radical? This looks like that, but wait a minute‚Ä¶ there's some extra growth now! This thing is so full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark>! It's even got a big, slide-shaped leaf growing on the top left. That's why it's the life radical.

You only have some ice and a stick for your spoon, because you're way up north. At the top of the world, there's only ice to eat, and ‚Äî if you're lucky ‚Äî a bit of stick for flavor. That's the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">north</mark> for you.

This is the radical for now. It's a bit tough to see, but it kind of looks like a fancy clock. The †Ü¢ is the top part hanging over the clock. The „É© shows a triangular clock face with a little cuckoo on top, peeking out to tell you this means now ‚Äî right now!

Put a cross in the mouth of a container full of all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> things you no longer need. They've all served their purpose but have gotten old, so it's now time to let them rest in peace under the cross. Goodbye, old things!

For better or worse, this looks enough like the poop emoji (üí©) to make this the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> radical. Try to remember it for its distinct outline. If it helps you can also note the private radical on the bottom of this one, since you should probably be in private when you poop‚Ä¶
This is a roof „Éº a flat roof with a little chimney sticking out. How cute!

This radical looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>! Well, a spoon that's been bent a lot by an angry person or a psychic. Go grab a spoon and try to bend it into this shape. Then hold on to it so you'll never forget that this is the spoon radical!

A leaf growing out of a‚Ä¶ mouth?? Look again and see the mouth is actually made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark>. The leaf here was just growing out of a crack on the side. Makes this stone mouth sculpture look kinda elegant, if you ask me. And obviously leaves don't grow on mouths, so whenever you see a leaf on a mouth, remember it's gotta be stone.
This looks just like a folding <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, am I right?

This looks like a little whiteboard to keep track of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark>s for the day. It's got three little legs on the bottom. And see those blank squares? They're sticky notes you can write your tasks on. Work tasks, school tasks, WaniKani reviews‚Ä¶ So what are your tasks for today? Imagine putting them in those little squares.

There's something draped over that stick. It's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>! It's the kind of towel you clean with, so it's sort of old and crusty, which is why it holds its square shape even when it's hanging on the stick like that.
The three horns represent the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark>, one of the most awesome dinosaurs ever.

See the criss-cross in the almost-square shape? That's the frames of a big window you can look out of. It's not perfectly shaped like a rice field, it's more artistic. That's why this is a window and Áî∞ is not.

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>. It looks like a skier going downhill (to the left), with their skis out in front and their poles out behind them. And when do people ski? In winter!

4.mnemonic: See the mouth and long, fang-like teeth of this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark>, which is facing to the right? You wouldn't want to get your hand stuck in there, that's for sure.
See how tall the stalks are with little bushy things at the top? It kind of looks like <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark>, if you use your imagination.

You'll have to complete the line on the right side in your mind, but see the rectangle <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bed</mark> and the pillows? This is totally a bed. That missing line is where you pulled back the covers when you got up this morning.

Doesn't this look like someone on their knees, holding their clasped hands out and begging for something (forgiveness, their life, a promotion, etc.)? That's why this radical is known as the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark>.

There's a cross branching off of this stool. Since it's branching out, we'll just call this the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> radical. I guess the tree this stool was made of is coming back to life in the form of a branch.

Doesn't this look like a top-down view of the frame of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>? There are the axles at the top and bottom, and the body in the middle between them. That's why this is the car radical.

Remember the guy from the big radical? Here he's bending his arms up to fasten some kind of belt, right across the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> of his body. It's one of those belts that just goes across your waist, which is actually perfect for such a big guy, since he really needs to secure his center (of gravity).

This radical looks like a person with a long dress running behind them. That's because they're all dressed up to go to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark>. You usually have to wear a long dress (or something formal) if you're going to a big ceremony, right? So when you see this radical, think of all the different ceremonies you might have to go to in your life and what you'll need to wear.

See the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>? It's facing to the left. What do you think this cliff is jutting out over? Maybe an ocean, or a valley? Cliffs love to jut out over things like that.

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> radical, since it looks like an ear. As much as a radical can, anyway. Those two middle lines are the ridges that guide the sound into your ear, and the lines that stick out to the right are where the ear attaches to your head.

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">energy</mark>. If you imagine a train under this radical, then the lines would be steam bursting out of it, flowing back from the front of the train (on the left) as it goes chugging along. Steam was the best way to generate energy back in the day, you know? That's why this is the radical for energy.
See the little things sticking out of the ground? Those little things are pretty little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark>.

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> radical. See the person doing a flying dragon kick to the right? What do they hit the target with? Obviously their foot. Imagine that foot coming straight at your face. At that point, your only hope is that it's clean. Nobody wants a foot to the face, especially not a filthy foot.

Sure, this forehead is a bit square, but that's because it's the top part of the head (ÂÜÇ) radical. This is just the forehead part of that! You can even imagine this as the forehead of Frankenstein's monster, since his forehead was pretty square too.

You have a roof on top of what looks like a volcano. What's the roof covering? It's definitely covering the hole at the top. I guess someone thought if they built a roof on the hole, none of the lava could come out. But isn't there a hole in the chimney? Guess their theory had some holes in it‚Ä¶ Oh no, now lava is coming through the hole. RUN!!! RUN!!!!!!!!

Can you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark>? You could put these horns on anything. Donkeys, people, monkeys, and so on. That's exactly what we'll be doing when we learn kanji that have horns too.

This looks like the middle radical on top of a sideways leaf. What can you often find sitting on the middle of a leaf? An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>. Insects looove sitting right in the middle of leaves. That's why this is the insect radical.

This radical technically means person (like ‰∫∫), but we're going to shift the meaning a little bit. It's kind of like the person radical, but it's taller and skinnier, standing above the others and raising its fist to lead them. That's why this is a leader, not a regular person.

The leader (ÔΩ≤) radical has a little something extra on top of him ‚Äî he's got a casual cap on because it's his day off. And what does he like to do on his day off? He likes to loiter. Look at him just loitering around. What a loiterer.

A rice paddy needs power, and that power comes from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">man</mark>. Picture a rice paddy full of thick, wet mud. It's no easy field to work in, but this powerful man will bend over to rake and hoe tirelessly to make sure it thrives. What a man!

The king is hovering a drop of water over his head. He's acquired the ability to manipulate water at will, making him the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> of all water! If you think about how all life depends on water, that really makes him the master of everything‚Ä¶

Have you ever used one of those triangular rulers? This looks just like one of those, because this is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> radical. Just think of all the angles you could measure with this thing!

This looks like a regular arrow, but it's not. Let's call it the "not arrow." It can not move forward, because it's been stopped by some kind of line above it. Every arrow wants to fly, but this one is not going anywhere. Look at it, being all negated like that. Well, that's just what this radical does. It nots things.

You have two lines with legs below them. And what is that bit above the legs? Well, it's where you came from ‚Äî your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark>. Yep, between two legs is where you originated, no matter how you look at it.

Obviously, this looks just like the good ol' 3.14 something-something all people are supposed to learn about. It's the math symbol that has to do with circles... <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pi</mark>!

This is a few plates drying on a rack. They're stacked together in a line. Imagine reaching out and grabbing one of those plates for yourself. And you only need one, so let's call this radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>.

A pile of dirt fell on you and now your legs and (scuba) fins are sticking out from under it, turning <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">red</mark>. You know, because you've been stuck in the sun so long. Everything's all sunburned and red. Can scuba fins get a sunburn? Yeah, when it's red hot outside. That's why this means "red."

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>. Specifically raw rice, like the grain that grows out of the ground when rice is raw and fresh. When rice is particularly ripe, it'll kind of look like this at the top of the stalks. See the long leaves and the little rice tufts at the top? That's why this radical is "rice."

The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> radical looks a lot like the dirt radical. The difference is this one has a longer top horizontal line, which is for those broad warrior shoulders. The bottom line is also shorter, since it's the little cushion the samurai is sitting on. Samurai didn't just fight, you know. They sat on cushions and wrote poems and stuff too. This is a very sensitive samurai.

This eye has legs, since you have to let your eyes run over something in order to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> it. That's why those eyes need legs ‚Äî to see. They're wandering eyes, they want to see the world!!

This radical looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. What looks like the eye radical is its long spiral shell. The bottom part that looks like fins is its little legs poking out, helping the shellfish move around.
On the ground there are a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> coming out. You wouldn't want to step on those now, would you?

This radical looks like some sort of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark>. It faces to the left with a big hood over its head, and creepy arms slanting downward at the sides. Can you picture it?

In some poop you find something small. You lean in, carefully pull it out, and realize it's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>. What's that doing there? Well, it came from a cat, and cats love to eat thread when you aren't looking. And floss and hoodie strings and mouse tails‚Ä¶ But this time, just thread.

This radical looks like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>, specifically just the handle part. A good old curvy umbrella handle, so you can hang that umbrella on your arm when it stops raining.

Use your imagination to draw a circle outside this shape. The grids from the radical start to look like longitude and latitude lines on a globe, don't they? That's why this is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark>.

5.mnemonic: When you're in prison, your only task is to count every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angle</mark> in your cell. You count the angles of the walls and ceiling over and over again to pass the time. How many angles could there be in a room with four walls? Picture it and try to count those angles now.

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, since it looks like one. The two horizontal strokes are the head, the long left line is the whole edge of its blade, and the vertical line in the middle is its short handle. Kind of a strange axe, I admit, but an axe is an axe.

You have life on top of the moon (ignore that life is missing its little slide on the left side). What would life on the moon look like? Well, first of all, they have no air, so they probably look pretty <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> from asphyxiation. When you meet them, it turns out you're right. They're a civilization of blue people. Imagine them all living up there, being blue and Smurfy.
See the slide going into the dirt? What appears to be a slide here is actually a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark>, sliding into the dirt to be buried.

In prison, dreaming in bed is the only way to see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">color</mark>. Picture a dark, dank cell with four gray walls. Now imagine the colorful dreamscapes your bed would take you to every night. What a contrast! That's why a prison bed = color.

This radical already looks like a pair of rectangular <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark>, right? I guess those short lines in each feather are like the filaments of the feathers.

You have the radicals for loiter, two, and barb. Someone who uses two barbs on you while you're loitering really wants you to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">GO</mark>!! GO on, stop loitering outside of my convenience store, ya dang kids!

Underneath that hat are two bars of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark>, but under those there are some spikes. This is some kind of trap for people who try to take your gold. And why else would you make a trap? Everyone wants to protect their gold.
This is a very oddly shaped <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark>, but it's a key nonetheless.

This looks like a stick-figure foot on the left kicking at something, which makes it the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark>. See the shin and foot swinging up for the kick? You can think of that part on the right as the edge of a ball that's about to be kicked.

Think of an old-style <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark>. It's in a box-shaped holder lined with rice paper and sits on four legs (you can only see two from this angle though). You can imagine people using these before electricity, right? That's why this radical is a lantern.

This looks like something hooked around the corner of a mouth ‚Äî it's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark>! Use your imagination, because it's either a giant lip ring or a very small mouth. It's angular because kanji prefer straight lines, but try to picture it as the kind of studded, angular lip ring your trendy friend wore in high school.
This is the radical for meat. What's meat-like about this? Think of a nice square slab of meat with some beautiful ‰∫∫-shaped marbling lines in it. Seeing it now? Mmm, meat.

Under the hat there are two people <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meet</mark>ing in private. Look at them huddled up in there. They must have a reason to want to meet in such a private place, but that's not for you to judge. Maybe next time you have to meet with someone you'll hide under a hat with them too.

See the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> going around the mouth? Man, I wish I could grow a sweet mustache like this. (Sure, the mustache looks a lot like the head radical here, but just imagine it as a mustache this time!)

See that lid on top? It's actually a flying saucer. "Take me to your leader," say the aliens inside, arriving from a strange-looking moon. When do you think you'd see something like this? At <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">night</mark>. When people see UFOs or the moon, it's usually night. That's why this is the night radical.

Here we have the ground radical, with something underneath it. What likes lying in the ground, covered in mud? A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark>! Use your imagination and see if you can find the head near the top, the piggy tail at the bottom right, and the little piglets on the left, nestling up to this mama pig.

The towel is getting soaked with drops of liquid. That's because it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>ing. Get your towels and other clothes inside before they get soaked through from this rain!
See the person running? Don't confuse this with foot (Ë∂≥), though. The head is just a streak because this person is running so fast.

There are a bunch of lines coming out of a mouth. Think of them as speech lines in a little speech bubble. Those lines represent the things you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>.

This radical is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>. See the handlebars and the little light? And there's a platform at the bottom you can stand or sit on (if it's one of those nice motorized scooters).

Remember the eye radical? Imagine that's your eye now, and there's a drop of paint falling into it, making your eye color unique. Now it's what makes you you. It's what makes you your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark>.

A single drop (‰∏∂) is just water. But as soon as there are three, rising higher and higher, you know what's coming. A tsunami! Think of those drops as wave crests. Three whole tsunami waves, stacking up? That's a big tsunami.
You have ÂçÅ plus ÂçÅ (never mind that the left one is kinda curvy)... What do you get when you add these two kanji together? You get twenty.

On the top part of the head (ÂÜÇ) radical, there is a horn radical with one extra spike in the middle. This is a horned helmet with one extra spike. Who were famous for having horned helmets like that? The Vikings! That's why this radical is called Viking.

A rice paddy and some dirt ‚Äî dirt roads, in fact, because this is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark>. Small villages like this are mostly rice paddies and dirt (roads), you know? You could even think of this as a bird's-eye view of a village.

You have the legs of a bird with wings outspread, landing in the mouth of her nest to rest. And when does she go back to rest? When the sun sets in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">west</mark>! Imagine all the birds flying home as the sun sets. That's why this radical means west.

You know <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> from the X-Men? He has three claws that come out of his hand whenever he needs to fight, not at all unlike the radical you see here.

6.mnemonic: First of all, there's a cross making up the middle, which automatically makes this a religion-based radical. That cross is the frame of someone's body and the things coming off of it are wings. This is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angel</mark>.

You see a little drop of something on your plate. Oh no‚Ä¶ it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">BLOOD</mark>!!! Yep, you're bleeding. Now you have to wash that plate again ‚Äî just as soon as the bleeding stops. Don't worry, your platelets should stop the bleeding soon. Haha, get it? PLATE-lets? Like blood platelets? Japanese blood jokes.

This radical looks like the fire from the burner of a stove. That's because this is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> radical. You need to boil a bunch of water over some flames.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">city</mark>.

There's a lid on a lion. And you're stuck under the lid with the lion, which means you will surely meet your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark>. Or if you don't want to die, think of the poor lion. If you leave a lion under a lid for too long, death will come for it too. Either way, somebody's gonna die today.

Behind that tree the sun is rising in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark>. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.

You put on your hat and go outside to kick something white. It's a big white goose and you killed it with your kick. That's because you're going to cook and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> it. Yum!

Someone has a toe in their mouth. They are a fortune teller telling your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark>. But for her to do it, she has to take one of your toes and taste it. This better be a good fortune for you to let someone put your foot in their mouth.

This is a tree with a drooping slide shape on top. What causes the top of plants to sag? The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s. Imagine seeing how the heads of wheat or rice droop when they're ready for harvest. It will look like this radical. Look at all that ripe grain!

Under this roof is a pig with her little ones. Your pig, because it's your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">house</mark>! You keep your piggies inside where it's nice and warm. They're all members of your family, so they deserve to live in your house too.

This is like one of those <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark>s that have the little nose-wings going on too. Imagine you're looking at the jet from the top down, this is what it would look like. It's also why this is the jet radical.

This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>. See the sharp edge on the left and the tapered tip on top? And there's a little handle at the bottom for the... well, the handle. Be careful you don't cut yourself on this knife!

There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark> scooping up two drops of liquid. See the handle and the scoop part of the ladle? Imagine ladling some water into your mouth. Mmm.

This L-shaped radical is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark> radical, because "L" is for "Lion." It also looks like a lion's mouth being opened really, really wide. Imagine a lion opening its mouth to yawn. It looks like this radical!
When a stick figure has hair that drags on the ground and gets kicked all the time, you know that hair's gotta be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark>. Why is it so looooong?!

This radical is just like the katakana character "ma" („Éû). So let's keep things simple and make the radical mama. It even looks like a mama leaning over and gently tapping her baby to help them fall asleep.

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">neck</mark>. Look, you can see all the vertebrae stacked up, and the little ligaments that connect it to the base of the skull! That's why this is the radical for neck.

This is a very fluffy <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark>. See the two horns poking up and all its wool poking out to the side? It's so fluffy that you can hardly see its tiny little legs. What a cute sheep!

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> radical. See that sturdy slide holding a thousand people above a mouth? An open mouth can't support that much weight, but a strong tongue can ‚Äî it's the muscle of the mouth, after all.

This radical looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark>. See him facing left, with that threatening jawline and big pompadour hairstyle? Maybe imagine a couple scars on his face too. You know, real yakuza-like.

7.mnemonic: See the cool wing on the bottom? See the head with the neat feather coming out of the top? This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>. Tweet tweet!

If you boil a village, everything will turn <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black</mark>. Just imagine all those roads melting and coating everything in black tar. Picture it! It looks like Pompeii. (Oof, too soon?)

This looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> coming toward you in the water. See the sail billowing on top and the reflection on the water? Yep, that's a boat. The boatiest boat that ever boated.
This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">box</mark> is open. There could be any number of things inside, but for now all you need to know is the meaning of this radical, which is box.

You take your head and pack clay dirt around it to just above your mouth. You need the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> of your head for your helmet maker, and sending them a clay dirt mold of your head will just do the trick. That way they'll know your head's exact circumference!

Under a cliff, you spot a cross, slightly tilted. The cross is there to mark a famous <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> that once ruled the lands below the cliff. It's a pretty unique cross, so whenever you see it there under the cliff, you'll know it honors the clan who lived there.

This is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elephant</mark> ‚Äî or at least, a wannabe elephant. Look closely. It's actually a family of pigs, and the mama is wearing an elephant mask on her head for some reason. See the big ears and trunk on top? She wants to be an elephant so badly that she dressed up like one.

This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark>. Kind of a funny-looking fish, with a weird head on top, a squat scaly body, and a tail fanning out underneath it. See the fish? Yeah, you see it.

This radical already looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark>, right? A high gate with pillars on either side and two small gate doors, way up at the top for some reason. Worst gate ever in terms of security, but definitely still a gate.

The radicals ground and big make up this radical. There's a big guy on the ground... who is that big guy? Embarrassingly, it's your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark>. Feel the shame that he got knocked down on the ground. By what? Who? How? (It doesn't matter.)

A (modified) prison radical containing a person radical. What does a person experience in prison? <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Lack</mark>. Prison is all about lack ‚Äî lack of freedom, lack of the comforts of home, lack of privacy, lack of conversation. Yep, the life of a person in prison is defined by lack.

This kinda looks like a head with an arm under it pointing up at itself. That's why this radical means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>. One points to oneself when one wants to‚Ä¶ indicate oneself‚Ä¶

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">south</mark>. See how it's pointing south? You can think of the cross on top as a compass rose, and the arrow below (that ¬•-looking part) as pointing down south. It's a compass pointing nowhere but south!

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> radical ‚Äî the inking kind, not the postage kind. Why? Because it looks like a stamp stick! The top parts are thicker on one side so you can get a good grip. It even looks like the letter P ‚Äî which just happens to be the last letter in "stamp"!
What happens when you put a flat surface on top of a pair of legs? You get a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark>.

Who's in the coffin next to that child? It's his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">teacher</mark>. Teachers are pretty much dead around 3 p.m. every day, and it's the kids in their class who wear them down. It ain't easy being a teacher, you know.

This radical looks kind of like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark>, don't you think? With all the layers and stuff? Just picture the top part as a roof, and the drop-looking bit at the bottom as a giant temple bell, with a monk standing beside it and ringing it with a large wooden beam. You see this kinda thing every day at a temple.
This radical looks just like a top hat. That's why it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark>!
See the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wing</mark>? It's kind of like a bat wing with webbing. Either way, it's just a wing.

Flowers that grow out of the ground of a rice paddy after you bury fins there will grow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yellow</mark>. Why? Because yellow is the color of a fish's soul, so planting flowers over their fins will turn them into a nice, pretty yellow.

8.mnemonic: This radical is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> because it's covered on all sides but one (the one open side is where the cage door or gate is). There's nothing inside this cage because there's no gate, and whatever was inside has gotten out. I hope it wasn't rabid...

This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cape</mark>, like the kind a superhero would wear. Use your imagination to picture a hero facing left, with a cape tied around their neck and hanging down their back. With that cape on, they're ready to save the world!

This looks like the kind of building you'd find in a Japanese <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>. See the ornate roof and the stone foundation flaring out underneath, like a castle? The emperor lives in there. And wherever the emperor lives automatically becomes the capital city. That's why this radical is capital.
This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark>. See how the cloud is puffy on the bottom but has two lines up top? That's because a plane flew through it.

This radical is made up of two slightly different versions of the spoon radical. Look closely at these two spoons. <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Compare</mark> their differences, like the different angles in the bends of the spoons. It's like one of those "spot the difference" games where you compare two similar pictures. But this time it's with spoons.
Flying to the sun with wings is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark>! Or so Icarus thinks. Someone should probably tell him‚Ä¶

This looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark>, like the kind a pirate would wear. The flat line shows where the hand was cut off, and the hook is right above, ready to take its place. Yarrrr.

This radical looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark>. See the long, thick neck with the mane flowing to the right? What might look like a wing is actually the horse's four legs and its tail hanging down.
This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark>, spread out over the water. Imagine all the fish you can catch in this net!

Most of this radical is just the rice radical, but the top part is something coming to cut the rice from its stalk. That, my friend, is the sickle. See how the rice is still there? That's because it's in motion. The sickle is literally doing the cutting RIGHT NOW! (And don't confuse this with the grain Á¶æ radical!)
This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark> radical. See the head at the top with its long skinny body stretching down from it?

This is the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark>, like when something suits you. You find a hat on the ground, and when you pick it up, there's a mouth underneath. "It suits you! It suits you!" the mouth says. You try the hat on, and yup ‚Äî it really suits! It's weird getting fashion advice from a random mouth, but hey, it wasn't wrong.

Stick a table on top of a stool and you end up with a very dangerous <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>. Imagine hitting someone with this thing! Or, even better, imagine making someone sit on it. They'd be crushed mentally and emotionally and whatnot. Now that's a scary weapon.

9.mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>.
This radical kind of looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark>. The top part is a hand holding the brush handle, and the bottom part is the bristly tip.

This radical looks like a curvy letter B. What does B stand for? <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Building</mark>! This radical often shows up in kanji related to gatherings or to places where people come together‚Ä¶ like buildings.

There's the bottom of a shoe with spikes coming out of it. Only one kind of shoe is like this, and that's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>. You know, like those studded shoes athletes wear. Soccer cleats, baseball cleats, running cleats‚Ä¶ You knew they were called cleats, right?

A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> face, with the funny hat at the top, the silly eyes in the middle, and the big laughing mouth at the bottom. This thing is pretty cute, unlike a lot of clowns‚Ä¶

See all the arms sticking out of this radical? Those are for hanging lots of coats and things on, because this is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark>. Kind of a weird coat rack, but definitely a coat rack.

You're lost, but you've come across a signpost that says "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>" in all directions. "Correct," "correct," "correct," it says. No matter which way you go, it's the correct way! What a relief!

A drop of water will last for an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eternity</mark>. Especially if you drop it into an endless stream that never stops flowing. You can see these streams converging from all directions here, flowing for eternity.

Someone shoved horns onto your husband and said he has to fight for them now. They turned him into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark>! Now your husband has to fight for their amusement. Are you not entertained?!

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> radical. See the square fist in the center, grasping the handle of a dumbbell that has two heavy plates on the top and bottom? The radical just looks like it would be heavy, you know?

This radical looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> coming straight at you, doesn't it? You can't see the tail part because it's behind the bigger front cab of the helicopter. But you can see the front windows and the big spinning blade on top.

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">history</mark> radical. You can see a textbook and a couple crossed swords. Because that's basically how history works ‚Äî fight battles, record the results, and do it all over again. History!

This radical looks like a hat with some legs under it. If all you can see is legs, the person wearing the hat must really be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jammed in</mark> there. Have you ever tried to cram yourself into a hat so hard it covers your body? Yeah, didn't think so. But imagine how jammed in to that hat you'd be if you did.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark>.

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> radical. See how it's wide at the top, with a little stem sticking up, and narrow at the bottom? Just like a chili pepper. It's so spicy it can't even handle its own heat!

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> radical, because it looks like a new plant shoot has pushed its way up through layers of dirt, snow, and ice to announce the coming of spring. Spring is the season (and the radical) full of new, growing life!
See the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> shape here? There's its pointy head, its eyes, and its tentacles (two, anyway). Pretty squid-like if you ask me!

Kind of a strange <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark>, I'll admit, but one that will protect you from things trying to get in (that's why it has all the spikes). It's the best you can do, considering you're in a cloth tent.

There's a canopy with a grid-like frame near the top. It's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> with a window! Yurts are those dome-shaped huts nomads use. Once you've set up a canopy with a window frame, you've basically built one. Imagine gazing out that window, kicking back in your yurt. Yurt sweet yurt!

10.mnemonic: This looks like the west radical with a little something extra under it‚Ä¶ And if you ask for "a little something extra" in the Wild West, you're going to get a big ol' decanter of bourbon, moonshine, or some other kind of very strong <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> ‚Äî which happens to be exactly what this radical looks like! That extra line at the bottom is just the little bit of alcohol still left in the bottle.

This radical has a bean (the square in the middle) between the ground and some roots. That bean is going to turn into a plant someday. What will that plant produce? Great big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark>, like the ones from Jack and the Beanstalk.

This looks like a tree with something tied around its middle, holding it tight. If you untied that middle part you'd realize it's actually a bunch of little trees (aka twigs and sticks) tied in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark>!

This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Chinese</mark> radical. Why? Because it looks like a traditional Chinese pagoda! One of those towers with a bunch of tiered roofs, you know? Sure, lots of Asian countries have pagodas, but let's be honest ‚Äî the Chinese probably came up with them first.
Doesn't this radical look like one of those old-fashioned <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dynamite</mark> plunger things that gets pushed to set the fuse? That makes this dynamite!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fault</mark>.

A leaf-shaped protrusion coming out of a shellfish. What is it? The mysterious <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>! The geoduck is a giant clam so big that most of it grows outside its shell. If you've never seen a geoduck, look it up now. You'll never be able to unsee it.

In winter, your mouth longs for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>. You know, because your lips get cold and you want someone to warm them up. How do you think that whole mistletoe thing got started? Cold winter mouths, longing for a kiss. So just imagine the top part of this radical as some winter mistletoe (or holly leaves, since that's probably easier), and the bottom part as a kissy mouth.
If you kick a cliff twice you'll start a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark>! Oh no!

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means music! Êõ≤ even looks like a musical score with two notes in the middle. Huh? Real sheet music has more lines, you say? Hey, it's a radical ‚Äî we're saving ink, not performing Beethoven here.
This is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pope</mark> radical. Why? Because it looks like a pope hat! This one's got a big old cross on top, and it can only be worn by the pope.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sell</mark>.

This is the canopy radical with ice running down the back. If you hang out in a cold canopy like this you'll definitely get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark>. Imagine being sick and alone inside a cold canopy. Brrrr, oh no... ACHOO!

This radical looks like a little flight of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark>, don't you think? Also note it's being held up by a pillar or beam or something on the left side. After all, you don't want your stairs collapsing as you walk up them.
